result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Rachel L. Mayo

records.addlTxt:
3:45 PM Defendant Rachel L. Mayo appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Adam J Snavely appeared by video for Rachel L. Mayo.  Attorney Karl Peter Hayes in court for State of Wisconsin. Defense confirms receipt of criminal complaint, waive reading.  Defense wishes to proceed with a waiver of the preliminary hearing.  Waiver of preliminary hearing.  Rights given.  Court finds defendant is making a knowing and voluntary waiver of right to preliminary examination.  Court finds probable cause.  Bound over for arraignment on an information.  State to e-file information in court and provides copies to defense.  Defense waives formal reading of information.  Not guilty pleas entered by court.  Bond continued.
Judicial Pretrial - in court scheduled for December 20, 2022 at 11:30 am.
Judicial Pretrial - in court on December 20, 2022 at 11:30 am.

Defense indicates he is withdrawing.  Defendant confirms.  Court grants Attorney Moon's motion to withdraw.  Judge Bloom authorizes judicial transfer back to Vilas County, judicial to complete application. Court sets status of counsel hearing on Sept 9, 2022, at 11:30 am.
